After extensive research I got this solution that can actually help:
- Avoid hot water
- Stop using H&S or any anti-dandruff shampoo altogether immediately. The reason why is because H&S attacks the fungi but also create a clean plate to the fungi to regrow again the moment you stop using it, worsening inflammation by a lot. Will take a couple of weeks of adaptation, but it helps a lot.
- stop using shampoo so much, once a month is perfectly fine
- use natural good oils and moisturizers (coconut oil and olive can be good) to keep up with the dryness and the flakes
- it's actually possible to drop shampoo altogether, a little harder to keep hygiene tho.

Growing my hair out has (imo) made my scalp healthier than it's ever been whereas when I used to get haircuts every other week, I'd experience pretty severe bouts of dandruff while using products like H&S. It's like a vicious cycle where the "solution" is worse than the problem and may actually exacerbate it.

I believe we who live in countries like the US are in the process of altering our genetics in a way that's never been seen before in human history, through pollution and the synthetic chemicals we breath, ingest and apply to our skin, and this is causing our bodies to react in unprecedented ways. Scientific breakthroughs have certainly helped remove a number of obstacles that threatened our progress as a species, but there is a limit to what we should be using to fix seemingly minor issues that could cause major problems down the road.

Head and Shoulders (plus all other shampoos which lather a lot)  are real effective on my dandruff ONLY IF used once every 2-3 days.  Fact is, stripping away all the grease makes the scalp dry and irritated, causing dandruff.  While not shampooing for too long makes the scalp too greasy and also causes dandruff.  So y'all need to hit that sweet spot between too much grease causing dandruff vs. too harsh detergents causing dandruff.  For me that sweet spot is 2-3 days, and only a pea-sized amount of shampoo at that!

I've had horrible dandruff my entire life and I've found conventional dandruff shampoo to be only slightly effective, but significantly irritating- driving the underlying inflammatory process. I've had better results ditching the Head&Shoulders and using tea tree shampoo with an exfoliating shampoo brush. You have to remove the top layer of dandruff flakes for the antifungal to really penetrate the scalp. I use a small amount of coconut oil as a conditioner (yes, oil feeds the yeast, but the anti-inflammatory effect of coconut oil results in a net benefit, at least for me). Probiotics and a low sugar diet also help to reduce yeast levels in the microbiome.

I solved doing this:
1) Comb your hair carefully to remove dead skin twice a week (don't scratch too hard).
2) Don't wash your hair more than three times a week. If you have too because the skin is too itchy, use one day little amount of shampoo and the other day just water. Note: I didn't use anti dandruff shampoo, just delicate shampoo.
3) Dry your hair carefully. Umidity accelerates dandruff.
4) Wash your pillowcase often and now and then wash your pillow.

For people who have dandruff and have tried head and shoulders, like me and realize they dont work.
There are different kinds of skin conditions that can cause dandruff like symptoms. My specific problem was that I have very dry skin and that causes things to flake, actually this is the most common cause of dandruff, you are just not moisturizing enough. So in my case H&S did squat to alleviate the problem in fact it made the dandruff worse, the sulfates just dried out my skin even more. I cured my dandruff with a normal conditioner which added a moisture barricade to my hair. So before going out there to buy that second bottle of H&S, go actually to your local skin doctor and get another opinion. Or at least give the conditioner aisle a try, also never buy the shampoo+conditioner products. Get them separately and use conditioner profusely if for the first time in a long time.

I remember reading from an old doctor's book that the scalp fungus feeds off of plant oils (coconut oil, etc.) so the more plant oils you put on your scalp it just feeds it and causes it to spread. What slows it down is mineral oil (petroleum jelly, baby oil, etc.) because it is synthetic and the fungus can't digest it so it slows the spread of the fungus.
So far i used petroleum jelly (with aloe vera extract) on my hairline/forehead and it actually helped, my forehead is usually flaky and scaly and it smoothened out well, you just have to be consistent with it. Hoping to try some on my scalp when i middle-part my hair next wash.

I have scalp psoriasis so i get pretty bad flakes in my hair sometimes. The best thing i have done to combat it and actually get rid of it for months at a time is using (1) manitoba harvest hemp oil unrefined-cold pressed ( rub it in and let it soak over night if possible, sometimes i just do an hour before i hop in the shower), (2) dr. bronner castile soap ( i used the non scented baby version) to wash out the hemp seed oil in the shower, and finally a quick rub in and rinse with (3) braggs organic apple cider vinegar with the mother. (while in the shower still of course). Do that every other day for the first week or two and then start tapering it off (every 3 or 4 days) as you see it start clearing until you get to the point where you just need to do it here and there as needed. Buying little squeeze bottles for each helps a lot with application.

Hope that helps someone!

I use a salicylic acid + sulfur soap bar. The bar also has an oil base so it helps in preventing my skin from drying out. Salicylic acid helps to shed the skin faster and the sulfur helps to keep the right amount of microbiome on my scalp. I only use it once a week. I used to use selenium sulfide but I realise when I use it for a long period of time (over 10 years), the fungus learns to be resistant that it just doesn't work and my dandruff came back. Ok, here's my approach for anyone not interested in a radical change of lifestyle and suffering heavy dandruff for months waiting for a change:
Get a nice shampoo and conditioner for your hair style and use that most days. Get a clear (no too much components) shampoo for oily scalps to use once every 3 washes when you start getting mild dandruff. I go about a month or two like this without much issues.
Get a dandruff shampoo and maybe conditioner to use when you get heavy flakes and do two or three washes in a row to starve and kill the fungus. Then go back to the usual routine.

If it's severe, be sure of changing your pillowcase weekly, surely after using dandruff specific products. Also leave your pillow out in the sun between changes if you can.

I hope it helps!

That's great, check out this paragraph about "Body dandruff" from "From Russia With Chilli and Garlic Sauce (Memoirs of Johnny Two Kebabs) "Body Dandruff" As he tended to do when he was nonplussed Johnny sat around for a few minutes, lit a cigarette and scratched himself. This was a nervous habit which had started at the time he had caught a dose of scabies in a cheap hotel room in King’s Cross. He had brought a young lady back to a hotel in front of St Pancras station one night, he had rented the room for only an hour, but the consequences had remained ever since. He had managed to get rid of the parasites through a lotion the doctor had prescribed but the experience meant that in future when he felt nervous he would begin to scratch himself. He would start with his chest and scratch until bits of skin started to flake off creating a sort of “Body dandruff” then he would move to his armpits where he would work away for a minute or so as if he were trying to dislodge something which had got caught there and finally he would finish by scratching his scalp in a sort of circular motion.

Either with salicylic acid( it takes out the outer layer of skin cells)
Or ketoconazole (it kills the fungus)
Or both.

Recently I grew tired of using the medicated shampoo, and stopped it. (As you know, doctors are the worst kind of patients)

I had huge amount of dandruff,
The amount I remember in highschool when I didn't take any treatment...

You shed skin. When you shed a lot of skin it comes out in clusters that is dandruff. What causes dandruff ? A fungus that eats sebum in your scalp and poops out stuff that some people's body think is dangerous. So, it starts producing and shedding skin rapidly. Chemicals that limits the population of that fungus are Zinc Pyrithione, Selenium Sulfide, Piroctone Olamine.

It might be of interest that this yeast (Malassezia globosa) is also involved in seborrhoeic eczema (a.k.a. seborrhoeic dermatitis), affecting the face, sides of the nose, forehead, behind the ears, inside the ear canals, and other areas. In my experience as a user, anti-dandruff shampoo works great as a treatment for those areas too. The redness and flaking have the same cause, (yeast degrades skin fat [sebum], fatty acids produced cause an inflammatory response), and the yeast can be supressed in the same way.

In my own case, I have found it also effective for the related fungal infections of tinea pedis (athletes foot), tinea cruris (jock itch/ringworm) and the skin pigmenting tinea versicolor (Pytiriasis). Same method applies. Wet area, apply shampoo, foam in, leave on for a minute or two, rinse off and dry. I apply such shampoo on a sponge in the shower, to my scalp and anywhere else my experience indicates it might be of benefit. People who have fungal problems on one area of the body tend to be prone to fungal problems on other areas. NOTE: I merely relate this as personal testimony of how it works for me ... I am not giving medical advice.

You'll find these antifungals are pretty generic; that is, zinc pyrithione is also used to stop fungal rot in fencing timber! Other antifungals, like the azole group, e.g. ketoconazole, also kill or inhibit fungi and will have the same effect. To lean more,wiki search on fungi, zinc pyrithione, piroctone olamine, selenium sulphide/sulfide, ketoconazole, Malasezzia.

Some people are more prone to it than others, but most people will experience it at some point in their life.

Once I switched to "organic"-type shampoos (the ones that say on the label no parabans, no sulfates, and other buzzwords) my dandruff went away completely. Actually excessive showering with shampoo dries out your skin and sheds your skin differently. A great commercial indeed. The head & shoulders marketing team has come up with a great plan to market their product.

However, what one has to understand is H&S works more like a disinfectant or an antimicrobial agent on the scalp. What they failed to inform in the ads is the importance of probiotics. The fungal infection is a direct result when the balance between the good and bad microbes is thrown off. This is when there's fungal overgrowth. Pre and probiotics taken orally and probiotics like apple cider vinegar applied over the scalp is the actual way to deal with the issue.

Applying these chemicals over the scalp is like dealing with the infection with the help of antibiotics. H&S actually wipes out even the left over good microbes from the scalp aiding the fungal growth on the long run. It isn't a permanent fix. Look into probiotics.

Now this may just be semantics, but do half of everybody on earth really suffer from dandruff? Maybe half of everyone has it, but how many of those people are really bothered by it, and what level of bother adds up to actual suffering? What is suffering really? We all know the dictionary definition, but where is the gradation where annoyance becomes suffering? If we could come up with a definitive number, what about individuality? Some people have higher or lower pain thresholds than average. Something that may not bother one person all that much may be a real problem for someone else.

Tying back into the main point of this video, Head & Shoulders product placement, I am not bothered by dandruff because I use head and shoulders. With a significant proportion of the world population that find dandruff to be bothersome, how many of them are using Head & Shoulders (or some generic version of it), and therefore are not bothered by it in spite of having the condition? Would it be fair to say Head & Shoulders reduces the overall amount of suffering in the world?

I understand that Head&Shoulders sponsored this video, and thank you Derick for keeping the video focused on the science, as much as possible, despite the fact that you could not avoid certain, blatant Head&Shoulders promotions.  This video, however, fails to address four key potentials-  1) The scalp's increased skin cell production is an evolutionary advantage for the human, and not the fungus, 2) The scalp's increased skin cell production is an evolutionary advantage for the fungus, and not the human, 3) The scalp's increased skin cell production is an evolutionary for both the human, and the fungus, or 4) The scalp's increased skin cell production is not an evolutionary advantage to either species, and it is simply an inconsequential side effect for ~50% of humans (albeit, if itchiness and flaking can be considered a disadvantage, then this option can be ruled out as these are known side effects of dandruff).  Does anyone know which of these potentials is the case?  Is there any way to know for sure?  After all, there are inconceivably many aspects of modern society that can prevent us from knowing the potentially adverse consequences of not being able to ramp up skin cell production?

I understand that as an educator you still have to make money, but please don't mix education and business because the result is merely corporate propaganda. That's not to say that propaganda doesn't deal in facts, it usually does, but only that those facts tend to be presented in a one-sided fashion. I am eminently surprised at how the people in this comment section will lap up corporate propaganda uncritically if it comes from the mouth of someone with scientific credentials being interviewed by a trusted host.

The science of dandruff is genuinely interesting, and the researcher who found dinosaur dandruff was a good pick. But imagine how it would undermine your presentation of his research if he had payed you to interview him. In that case, I am more concerned as to what financial motive he has in presenting the research than the research itself. We don't expect a critical analysis of LootCrate or SquareSpace or whoever is sponsoring a given video, but presenting the the science of dandruff through the lens of Head and Shoulders (who have a vested interest in pathologizing the subject and offering an easy to purchase solution) is questionable to say the least.

It may seem trivial, like I'm looking for trouble where there isn't any, but with American culture gradually spiraling into fact-averse fascism, any opportunity to enhance the public's ability to think critically and independently should not be glossed over.

What in hell am I talking about? you all ask. Healthy skepticism, folks, healthy skepticism. I just retired after 40 years of practicing medicine, and the content of this video really struck a familiar chord in me. This seeming "free lunch" from Procter and Gamble isn't free -- there's a price attached to it. It's tempting to credit Derek with the clear and engaging presentation of the content, but I guarantee you that he was just along for the ride. This was a highly choreographed presentation that P&G gives regularly to influential media arbiters of scientific public opinion. And it was well done. There were no problems with inaccurate factual content. They enlightened us regarding some aspects of yeast colonization of the scalp. They told the truth. Some of it, anyway, and spun slightly to meet their needs. This video is really propaganda-lite, very similar to the aggressively manipulative, truth mauling "educational material" with which the pharmaceutical industry (including P&G) attempts to buy the minds of physicians. It's easier to understand the potential pitfalls if you know the right questions to ask which, of course, the average person doesn't. Questions like: (1) is dandruff really a problem, or is it just the footprints of a commensal, symbiotic relationship we've had with these yeast organisms since the dawn of time (if dinosaurs and proto-birds had it, this possibility seems more likely), (2) we know that chemicals applied to the scalp turn up in the cerebrospinal fluid, which bathes the brain, via the penetrating veins which communicate between the epidermis of the scalp and the subarachnoid space. Is this KNOWN to be safe? (3) treatment never eradicates the organism, just suppresses it, so that it rebounds when treatment is stopped (they didn't tell us that, did they?) In light of that, are there simpler, less expensive options with less potential toxicity? (4) is it possible that this organism is there for a reason? Maybe serves a purpose? It wouldn't be the first time that our hubris lead us down the wrong road (i.e. conflating the ABILITY to do something with the NECESSITY to do it.

As someone who had really bad dandruff and skin problems, Head And Shoulders never worked. Infact a lot of the chemicals in Head And Shoulders irritated my scalp and made my skin shed more and made it worse. I had to switch to a dermatologically tested shampoo. People don't really understand what the actual ingredients that are used in Head And Shoulders and how harsh and unforgiving they can be, including sodium chloride, Sodium Lauryl Sulfate and Sodium Benzoate. Make sure to buy shampoos that have ketoconazole in them and that have more common and natural ingredients. The scientist who said that Head And Shoulders could switch people's genes is a bit of a stretch to make. I don't know how you can possibly change someone's genes in only 3 weeks using only a topical shampoo, he's basically saying that Head And Shoulders has the power or equivalency of gene/DNA editing. If they submitted these results to an independent third party for analysis or peer review, then maybe they could get away with making these claims. But if its only inhouse scientists then, you can basically make any results you want.

comment_text: Would you trust a tobacco company to tell you the science of smoking? H&S job is to sell the most shampoo possible, and I wouldn't be shocked if it's not as straight forward as they make it seem in the video. After all, if the goal is to reduce dandruff, the outcome measured should be the amount of dandruff, not a gene expression that might be related and a fungus we think may be involved but lives on everyone's scalp regardless. Their estimate of 50% of people having dandruff is likely inflated by stretching the definition because the dead skin has to come of at some point. Tobacco companies would also talk about seemingly related facts that work in their favor, like "no throat irritation in those that took their 30 day challenge," and this fungus science sounds like the crafted side discussion that's designed to sell instead of a randomized consumer test that compares no shampoo use to various shampoos with measured amount of daily dandruff along with other factors. Was the active ingredient in the shampoo even mentioned? The product may work and be great, but whenever the facts are coming from a company they need to be approached with skepticism. A company isn't going to spend time and money on research and educating people unless it makes them money back in some way. They'll never sell you a cure for dandruff you take once, but they will sell you a temporary solution you have to use every day.

This video inspired me to look up how that stuff works, so I could compare to how H&S works.. and now I know. The common factor is the fungus, and the differentiating factor is how the shampoo solves the problem. H&S controls the fungus population to slow down the death and flaking of cells to more normal levels. Coal Tar contains keratoplastics, which help shed the dead skin faster.

For those seeking remedies for dandruff, I'll share my experience. I'm 24 and had dandruff from my early teen. I tried almost all shampoo and oil on the planet, on a daily basis, just to get rid of it. Unfortunately none worked. Finally I figured out a work around, after loosing a good amount of hair. It's not which brand of shampoo or what kind of oil you put on the head, but instead the key is never to leave your scalp dry and the timing(not AM or PM, but timing relative to you taking bath) of application of oil. What worked for me is this. I'll apply shampoo(head and shoulders) once a week (mostly Sunday mornings) and after 2-3 hours after bath, when the head becomes dry, apply a lot of oil on the scalp, to maintain wetness of scalp. Any oil can help, I tried coconut and castor oil. Again I'll take another bath at night with fresh water only. For the rest of the week, I'll apply oil 2 hours before bath, and rinse the head with only fresh water, one time daily(mostly nights). Now I can say, my head is dandruff free, almost out of magic. Wish I should have figured out this earlier, before losing my thick hair. Maybe someone else can benefit from my experience. Maybe it's the anti fungal property of oil, not allowing the fungus to develop(remember to apply oil just when your head is dry after shampooing) and grow...

For 32 years i had Dandruff, flakes big as 1cm square. Tried all sorts of stuff, Sulfate shampoos, Olive oil, Beer, Vinegar, Sodium bicarbonate, all natural shampoos like nettle poo and even tried the "no poo" thing for few months (this had a visible change to better, but i didn't solve the issue).  Head and shoulders (all types i could find) and on the end, few moths ago a dermatologist gave a prescription of a Sulfur powder with some liquid, so i could apply it from the bottle to my scalp. After the first treatment i saw results after the 3rd i had no more dandruff. First time after 32 years i'm flakeless :)
